questionListItems.title: How do I register the death of my next-of-kin after receiving a court order on his/her presumption of death?

answer.body: You may report the presumption of death to ICA online at https://go.gov.sg/ica-death-presumption.

questionListItems.title: How do I request for a verification letter or certificate that provides details about the deceased's children and spouse?

answer.body: You may contact ICA at ica_dpu_rbd@ica.gov.sg on this request.

questionListItems.title: How long does it take for trusted persons to be notified when the deceased has passed away?

answer.body: If the user has selected the option for the Trusted Person(s) to view the document(s) after his/her death. The Trusted Person(s) would be able to view the document(s) in My Legacy Vault, by logging in using their Singpass, once the death of the user has been reported. We currently do not have a notification system to inform the Trusted Person(s) that the person has passed away and will work on including this feature in My Legacy.

questionListItems.title: Would my Trusted person(s) whom I have granted access to the documents in My Legacy Vault be automatically granted legal rights to act on my behalf?

answer.body: The purpose of the My Legacy vault is to store important pre-planning documents and share them with the Trusted Person(s). However, the sharing of your pre-planning documents via My Legacy vault will not give your Trusted Person(s) legal rights to act on your behalf. You can also find more information in My Legacy website https://mylegacy.life.gov.sg/when-death-happens/wills-and-inheritance/.

questionListItems.title: Is there an option for me to grant access to my Trusted Person(s) to my documents in My Legacy Vault only after I pass away?

answer.body: We would like to inform you that users of My Legacy vault have the option to grant permission to their Trusted Person(s) to view selected documents only after the user has passed on.

questionListItems.title: What are the options in My Legacy Vault on sharing access of my documents to my Trusted Person(s)?

answer.body: Currently, My Legacy vault allows the users to choose from three viewing access options for the Trusted Person(s) i.e. "No Viewing Access", "View Now", or "View after death".

questionListItems.title: What will happen to the joint property if one of the owner(s) passed away?

answer.body:
If the property is under joint tenancy, the person's share in the flat will be transferred to the remaining owner(s). For HDB, the owner(s) can retain the existing flat provided that they:

  • are a Singapore Citizen (SC) or Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR)

  • are at least 21 years old; and

  • satisfy HDB's eligibility rules and conditions to own a flat.


You can refer to the following page on HDB https://www.hdb.gov.sg/residential/living-in-an-hdb-flat/changing-owners-occupiers/retain-flat-following-life-events under the title "Demise of joint owner" for more information.

questionListItems.title: Is it possible for me to leave my HDB flat to a non next-of-kin?

answer.body:
You may wish to consider writing a will to ensure that the ownership of the HDB flat is distributed according to your wishes. 
 
 In the absence of a will, your flat and other assets will be distributed in accordance with the Intestate Succession Act (ISA).
 
 By writing a will, you can ensure that your inheritance will be managed according to your wishes.

questionListItems.title: How do I proceed to settle the inheritance after the death of my family member?

answer.body: You can check if your late next-of-kin left a will on the management of his/her money, property and assets (i.e. estate). You may refer to the following page on My Legacy for more information: https://mylegacy.life.gov.sg/when-death-happens/wills-and-inheritance/

questionListItems.title: Can I create a new will using My Legacy vault?

answer.body:
The Vault in My Legacy provides a secure storage space for members of the public to upload official documents to share with their loved ones. The My Legacy website also provides a simple guide on https://mylegacy.life.gov.sg/end-of-life-planning/write-a-will/how-to-write-a-will


However, the My Legacy website is unable to create a Will, as some members of public may require legal advice from a professional on the execution of the Will. We have shared your request with the team and they will take this into consideration for future reviews of My Legacy website.

questionListItems.title: How do I make changes to my Lasting Power of Attorney?

answer.body:
To make changes to your appointed Donee (including adding an additional Donee) for a registered LPA, you would need to revoke your existing LPA and make a new one. The steps to revoke an LPA are as follows:

  1. Complete and sign the revocation form: https://www.msf.gov.sg/docs/default-source/default-document-library/revocation_form.pdf.

  1. Take reasonable steps to give written notice to every Donee that you are revoking the LPA by delivering it personally, sending it via post, or if the postal address is not known, via email

  2. Inform the Public Guardian of the revocation by providing the following items to the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG) by post or email:

  1. The completed and signed revocation form, and

  2. A photocopy of your ID.

  1. Pay the revocation fee of $30 via Office of the Public Guardian Online (OPGO) - MSF. OPG will provide instructions on how to make payment via email before processing your revocation.


The Public Guardian may also require you to provide further information or documents before revoking the registered LPA.

After submitting the revocation form, you may then proceed to make a new LPA on Office of the Public Guardian Online (OPGO) - MSF. Please note that you will need to have the LPA certified by a Certificate Issuer again - Find an LPA Certificate Issue before the new LPA can be submitted for registration.

questionListItems.title: Is my Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA) still effective after I die?

answer.body: The LPA will be cancelled upon the death of donor.

questionListItems.title: Where can I find more information on making a Lasting Power of Attorney?

answer.body: You can refer to: https://mylegacy.life.gov.sg/end-of-life-planning/make-a-lasting-power-of-attorney/ to find out more.

questionListItems.title: I am a Certificate Issuer and my details listed in OPGO is inaccurate. How do I make changes to it?

answer.body: Please email enquiry@publicguardian.gov.sg for further assistance on updating the details.

Advance Care Planning (ACP) is the process of planning for your current and future healthcare. ACP helps you to communicate to your loved ones and healthcare team about your values and how these values shape your healthcare preferences. In the event you are unable to make decisions or speak for yourself, your ACP guides your loved ones and healthcare team to make decisions in your best interest.


There are 3 different types of ACPs:

  • General ACP, for people who are generally healthy or has early-stage chronic diseases

  • Disease-specific ACP, for people who have progressive, life-limiting illnesses and are at risk of suffering multiple complications

  • Preferred Plan of Care ACP, for people who are approaching the end of their lives and are not expected to live beyond the next 12 months


When you prepare your ACP on My Legacy, you are filling up the general ACP. If you are receiving medical care at a public healthcare institution, you can ask your care team to arrange an ACP session for you. The ACP facilitator will advise you accordingly, depending on your health status.


If you are not receiving treatment at any public healthcare institution, you can contact a community ACP facilitator on My Legacy. Some ACP facilitators also offer tele-ACP services, which allows you to meet with them online via video conferencing.
